Mathematical Neuropsychology Personality Positive Quantitative Social Applied psychology Applied behavior analysis Clinical Community Consumer Counseling Critical Educational Environmental Ergonomics Forensic Health Humanistic Industrial organizational Legal Medical Military Music Occupational health Political Religion School Sport Traffic Lists Disciplines Organizations Psychologists Psychotherapies Publications Research methods Theories Timeline Topics Psychology portal v t e Psychology science behavior mind Psychology includes study conscious unconscious phenomena as well as feeling thought It an academic discipline immense scope Psychologists seek an understanding emergent properties brains all variety phenomena linked those emergent properties joining this way broader neuroscientific group researchers As social science it aims understand individuals groups by establishing general principles researching specific cases In this field professional practitioner researcher called psychologist can be classified as social behavioral cognitive scientist Psychologists attempt understand role mental functions in individual social behavior while also exploring physiological biological processes that underlie cognitive functions behaviors Psychologists explore behavior mental processes including perception cognition attention emotion intelligence subjective experiences motivation brain functioning personality This extends interaction between people such as interpersonal relationships including psychological resilience family resilience other areas Psychologists diverse orientations also consider unconscious mind Psychologists employ empirical methods infer causal correlational relationships between psychosocial variables In addition in opposition employing empirical deductive methods some especially clinical counseling psychologists at times rely upon symbolic interpretation other inductive techniques Psychology has been described as hub science in that medicine tends draw psychological research via neurology psychiatry whereas social sciences most commonly draws directly from sub disciplines within psychology While psychological knowledge often applied assessment treatment mental health problems it also directed towards understanding solving problems in several spheres human activity By many accounts psychology ultimately aims benefit society majority psychologists are involved in some kind therapeutic role practicing in clinical counseling school settings Many do scientific research on wide range topics related mental processes behavior typically work in university psychology departments teach in other academic settings e g medical schools hospitals Some are employed in industrial organizational settings in other areas such as human development aging sports health media as well as in forensic investigation other aspects law Contents Etymology definitions History Beginning experimental psychology Consolidation funding Disciplinary organization Institutions Boundaries Major schools thought Biological Behavioral Cognitive Social Psychoanalysis Existential humanistic theories Themes Personality Unconscious mind Motivation Development Genes environment Applications Mental testing Mental health care Education Work Military intelligence Health well being social change Research methods Controlled experiments Other forms statistical inference Technological assays Computer simulation Animal studies Qualitative descriptive research Program Evaluation Contemporary issues in methodology practice Metascience Confirmation bias Replication Misuse statistics WEIRD bias Unscientific mental health training Ethics Humans Other animals References Sources Further reading External links Etymology definitions word psychology derives from Greek roots meaning study psyche soul psych breath spirit soul logia study research Latin word psychologia was first used by Croatian humanist Latinist Marko Maruli in his book Psichiologia de ratione animae humanae in late th century early th century earliest known reference word psychology in English was by Steven Blankaart in in Physical Dictionary which refers Anatomy which treats Body Psychology which treats Soul In William James defined psychology as science mental life both its phenomena conditions This definition enjoyed widespread currency decades However this meaning was contested notably by radical behaviorists such as John B Watson in his manifesto defined discipline psychology as acquisition information useful control behavior Also since James defined it term more strongly connotes techniques scientific experimentation Folk psychology refers understanding ordinary people as contrasted with that psychology professionals History Main article History psychology ancient civilizations Egypt Greece China India Persia all engaged in philosophical study psychology In Ancient Egypt Ebers Papyrus mentioned depression thought disorders Historians note that Greek philosophers including Thales Plato Aristotle especially in his De Anima treatise addressed workings mind As early as th century BC Greek physician Hippocrates theorized that mental disorders had physical rather than supernatural causes In China psychological understanding grew from philosophical works Laozi Confucius later from doctrines Buddhism This body knowledge involves insights drawn from introspection observation as well as techniques focused thinking acting It frames universe as division interaction between physical reality mental reality with an emphasis on purifying mind in order increase virtue power An ancient text known as Yellow Emperor s Classic Internal Medicine identifies brain as nexus wisdom sensation includes theories personality based on yin yang balance analyzes mental disorder in terms physiological social disequilibria Chinese scholarship focused on brain advanced in Qing Dynasty with work Western educated Fang Yizhi Liu Zhi Wang Qingren Wang Qingren emphasized importance brain as center nervous system linked mental disorder with brain diseases investigated causes dreams insomnia advanced theory hemispheric lateralization in brain function Distinctions in types awareness appear in ancient thought India influenced by Hinduism central idea Upanishads distinction between person s transient mundane self eternal unchanging soul Divergent Hindu doctrines Buddhism have challenged this hierarchy selves but have all emphasized importance reaching higher awareness Yoga range techniques used in pursuit this goal Much Sanskrit corpus was suppressed under British East India Company followed by British Raj in s However Indian doctrines influenced Western thinking via Theosophical Society New Age group which became popular among Euro American intellectuals Psychology was popular topic in Enlightenment Europe In Germany Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz applied his principles calculus mind arguing that mental activity took place on an indivisible continuum most notably that among an infinity human perceptions desires difference between conscious unconscious awareness only matter degree Christian Wolff identified psychology as its own science writing Psychologia empirica in Psychologia rationalis in This notion advanced further under Immanuel Kant established idea anthropology with psychology as an important subdivision However Kant explicitly notoriously rejected idea experimental psychology writing that empirical doctrine soul can also never approach chemistry even as systematic art analysis experimental doctrine in it manifold inner observation can be separated only by mere division in thought cannot then be held separate recombined at will but still less does another thinking subject suffer himself be experimented upon suit our purpose even observation by itself already changes displaces state observed object In Ferdinand Ueberwasser designated himself Professor Empirical Psychology Logic gave lectures on scientific psychology though these developments were soon overshadowed by Napoleonic Wars after which Old University M nster was discontinued by Prussian authorities Having consulted philosophers Hegel Herbart however in Prussian state established psychology as mandatory discipline in its rapidly expanding highly influential educational system However this discipline did not yet embrace experimentation In England early psychology involved phrenology response social problems including alcoholism violence country s well populated mental asylums Beginning experimental psychology Wilhelm Wundt seated with colleagues in his psychological laboratory first its kind Gustav Fechner began conducting psychophysics research in Leipzig in s articulating principle Weber Fechner law that human perception stimulus varies logarithmically according its intensity Fechner s Elements Psychophysics challenged Kant s stricture against quantitative study mind In Heidelberg Hermann von Helmholtz conducted parallel research on sensory perception trained physiologist Wilhelm Wundt Wundt in turn came Leipzig University establishing psychological laboratory which brought experimental psychology world Wundt focused on breaking down mental processes into most basic components motivated in part by an analogy recent advances in chemistry its successful investigation elements structure material Paul Flechsig Emil Kraepelin soon created another influential psychology laboratory at Leipzig this one focused on more on experimental psychiatry Psychologists in Germany Denmark Austria England United States soon followed Wundt in setting up laboratories G Stanley Hall studied with Wundt formed psychology lab at Johns Hopkins University in Maryland which became internationally influential Hall in turn trained Yujiro Motora brought experimental psychology emphasizing psychophysics Imperial University Tokyo Wundt s assistant Hugo M nsterberg taught psychology at Harvard students such as Narendra Nath Sen Gupta in founded psychology department laboratory at University Calcutta Wundt students Walter Dill Scott Lightner Witmer James McKeen Cattell worked on developing tests mental ability Catell also studied with eugenicist Francis Galton went on found Psychological Corporation Wittmer focused on mental testing children Scott on selection employees Another student Wundt Edward Titchener created psychology program at Cornell University advanced doctrine structuralist psychology Structuralism sought analyze classify different aspects mind primarily through method introspection William James John Dewey Harvey Carr advanced more expansive doctrine called functionalism attuned more human environment actions In James wrote an influential book Principles Psychology which expanded on realm structuralism memorably described human stream consciousness interested many American students in emerging discipline Dewey integrated psychology with social issues most notably by promoting cause progressive education assimilate immigrants inculcate moral values in children One dogs used in Pavlov s experiment with surgically implanted cannula measure salivation preserved in Pavlov Museum in Ryazan Russia different strain experimentalism with more connection physiology emerged in South America under leadership Horacio G Pi ero at University Buenos Aires Russia placed greater emphasis on biological basis psychology beginning with Ivan Sechenov s essay Develop Psychology Sechenov advanced idea brain reflexes aggressively promoted deterministic viewpoint on human behavior Wolfgang Kohler Max Wertheimer Kurt Koffka co founded school Gestalt psychology not be confused with Gestalt therapy Fritz Perls This approach based upon idea that individuals experience things as unified wholes Rather than breaking down thoughts behavior into smaller elements as in structuralism Gestaltists maintained that whole experience important differs from sum its parts Other th century contributors field include German psychologist Hermann Ebbinghaus pioneer in experimental study memory developed quantitative models learning forgetting at University Berlin Russian Soviet physiologist Ivan Pavlov discovered in dogs learning process that was later termed classical conditioning applied human beings Consolidation funding One earliest psychology societies was La Soci t de Psychologie Physiologique in France which lasted first meeting International Congress Psychology sponsored by International Union Psychological Science took place in Paris in August amidst World s Fair celebrating centennial French Revolution William James was one three Americans among four hundred attendees American Psychological Association APA was founded soon after in International Congress continued be held at different locations in Europe with wider international participation Sixth Congress Geneva included presentations in Russian Chinese Japanese as well as Esperanto After hiatus World War Seventh Congress met in Oxford with substantially greater participation from war victorious Anglo Americans In Congress took place at Yale University in New Haven Connecticut attended by hundreds members APA Tokyo Imperial University led way in bringing new psychology East from Japan these ideas diffused into China American psychology gained status during World War during which standing committee headed by Robert Yerkes administered mental tests Army Alpha Army Beta almost million soldiers Subsequent funding behavioral research came in large part from Rockefeller family via Social Science Research Council Rockefeller charities funded National Committee on Mental Hygiene which promoted concept mental illness lobbied psychological supervision child development Through Bureau Social Hygiene later funding Alfred Kinsey Rockefeller foundations established sex research as viable discipline in U S Under influence Carnegie funded Eugenics Record Office Draper funded Pioneer Fund other institutions eugenics movement also had significant impact on American psychology in s s eugenics became standard topic in psychology classes During World War II Cold War U S military intelligence agencies established themselves as leading funders psychology through armed forces in new Office Strategic Services intelligence agency University Michigan psychologist Dorwin Cartwright reported that university researchers began large scale propaganda research in last few months war saw social psychologist become chiefly responsible determining week by week propaganda policy United States Government Cartwright also wrote that psychologists had significant roles in managing domestic economy Army rolled out its new General Classification Test engaged in massive studies troop morale In s Rockefeller Foundation Ford Foundation collaborated with Central Intelligence Agency CIA fund research on psychological warfare In public controversy called attention Army s Project Camelot Manhattan Project social science an effort which enlisted psychologists anthropologists analyze foreign countries strategic purposes In Germany after World War psychology held institutional power through military subsequently expanded along with rest military under Third Reich Under direction Hermann G ring s cousin Matthias G ring Berlin Psychoanalytic Institute was renamed G ring Institute Freudian psychoanalysts were expelled persecuted under anti Jewish policies Nazi Party all psychologists had distance themselves from Freud Adler G ring Institute was well financed throughout war with mandate create New German Psychotherapy This psychotherapy aimed align suitable Germans with overall goals Reich as described by one physician Despite importance analysis spiritual guidance active cooperation patient represent best way overcome individual mental problems subordinate them requirements Volk Gemeinschaft Psychologists were provide Seelenf hrung leadership mind integrate people into new vision German community Harald Schultz Hencke melded psychology with Nazi theory biology racial origins criticizing psychoanalysis as study weak deformed Johannes Heinrich Schultz German psychologist recognized developing technique autogenic training prominently advocated sterilization euthanasia men considered genetically undesirable devised techniques facilitating this process After war some new institutions were created some psychologists were discredited due Nazi affiliation Alexander Mitscherlich founded prominent applied psychoanalysis journal called Psyche with funding from Rockefeller Foundation established first clinical psychosomatic medicine division at Heidelberg University In psychology was integrated into required studies medical students After Russian Revolution psychology was heavily promoted by Bolsheviks as way engineer New Man socialism Thus university psychology departments trained large numbers students whom positions were made available at schools workplaces cultural institutions in military An especial focus was pedology study child development regarding which Lev Vygotsky became prominent writer Bolsheviks also promoted free love embraced doctrine psychoanalysis as an antidote sexual repression Although pedology intelligence testing fell out favor in psychology maintained its privileged position as an instrument Soviet Union Stalinist purges took heavy toll instilled climate fear in profession as elsewhere in Soviet society Following World War II Jewish psychologists past present including Lev Vygotsky R Luria Aron Zalkind were denounced Ivan Pavlov posthumously Stalin himself were aggrandized as heroes Soviet psychology Soviet academics was speedily liberalized during Khrushchev Thaw cybernetics linguistics genetics other topics became acceptable again emerged new field called engineering psychology which studied mental aspects complex jobs such as pilot cosmonaut Interdisciplinary studies became popular scholars such as Georgy Shchedrovitsky developed systems theory approaches human behavior Twentieth century Chinese psychology originally modeled U S with translations from American authors like William James establishment university psychology departments journals establishment groups including Chinese Association Psychological Testing Chinese Psychological Society Chinese psychologists were encouraged focus on education language learning with aspiration that education would enable modernization nationalization John Dewey lectured Chinese audiences in had significant influence on this doctrine Chancellor T sai Yuan p ei introduced him at Peking University as greater thinker than Confucius Kuo Zing yang received PhD at University California Berkeley became President Zhejiang University popularized behaviorism After Chinese Communist Party gained control country Stalinist Soviet Union became leading influence with Marxism Leninism leading social doctrine Pavlovian conditioning approved concept behavior change Chinese psychologists elaborated on Lenin s model reflective consciousness envisioning an active consciousness pinyin tzu chueh neng tung li able transcend material conditions through hard work ideological struggle They developed concept recognition pinyin jen shih which referred interface between individual perceptions socially accepted worldview failure correspond with party doctrine was incorrect recognition Psychology education was centralized under Chinese Academy Sciences supervised by State Council In Academy created Psychology Research Office which in became Institute Psychology Most leading psychologists were educated in United States first concern Academy was re education these psychologists in Soviet doctrines Child psychology pedagogy nationally cohesive education remained central goal discipline Disciplinary organization Institutions See also List psychology organizations In douard Clapar de Pierre Bovet created new applied psychology organization called International Congress Psychotechnics Applied Vocational Guidance later called International Congress Psychotechnics then International Association Applied Psychology IAAP considered oldest international psychology association Today at least international groups deal with specialized aspects psychology In response male predominance in field female psychologists in U S formed National Council Women Psychologists in This organization became International Council Women Psychologists after World War II International Council Psychologists in Several associations including Association Black Psychologists Asian American Psychological Association have arisen promote non European racial groups in profession world federation national psychological societies International Union Psychological Science IUPsyS founded in under auspices UNESCO United Nations cultural scientific authority Psychology departments have since proliferated around world based primarily on Euro American model Since Union has published International Journal Psychology IAAP IUPsyS agreed in each hold congress every four years on staggered basis International Union recognizes national psychology associations at least others exist American Psychological Association oldest largest Its membership has increased from in in present day APA includes divisions which since have steadily proliferated include more specialties Some these divisions such as Society Psychological Study Social Issues American Psychology Law Society began as autonomous groups Interamerican Society Psychology founded in aspires promote psychology coordinate psychologists across Western Hemisphere It holds Interamerican Congress Psychology had members in year European Federation Professional Psychology Associations founded in represents national associations with total individual members At least other international groups organize psychologists in different regions In some places governments legally regulate can provide psychological services represent themselves as psychologist APA defines psychologist as someone with doctoral degree in psychology Boundaries Early practitioners experimental psychology distinguished themselves from parapsychology which in late nineteenth century enjoyed great popularity including interest scholars such as William James indeed constituted bulk people called psychology Parapsychology hypnotism psychism were major topics early International Congresses But students these fields were eventually ostractized more less banished from Congress in Parapsychology persisted time at Imperial University with publications such as Clairvoyance Thoughtography by Tomokichi Fukurai but here it was mostly shunned by As discipline psychology has long sought fend off accusations that it soft science Philosopher science Thomas Kuhn s critique implied psychology overall was in pre paradigm state lacking agreement on overarching theory found in mature sciences such as chemistry physics some areas psychology rely on research methods such as surveys questionnaires critics asserted that psychology not an objective science Skeptics have suggested that personality thinking emotion cannot be directly measured are often inferred from subjective self reports which may be problematic Experimental psychologists have devised variety ways indirectly measure these elusive phenomenological entities Divisions still exist within field with some psychologists more oriented towards unique experiences individual humans which cannot be understood only as data points within larger population Critics inside outside field have argued that mainstream psychology has become increasingly dominated by cult empiricism which limits scope its study by using only methods derived from physical sciences Feminist critiques along these lines have argued that claims scientific objectivity obscure values agenda historically mostly male researchers Jean Grimshaw example argues that mainstream psychological research has advanced patriarchal agenda through its efforts control behavior Major schools thought Biological False color representations cerebral fiber pathways affected per Van Horn et al V Psychologists generally consider organism basis mind therefore vitally related area study Psychiatrists neuropsychologists work at interface mind body Biological psychology also known as physiological psychology neuropsychology study biological substrates behavior mental processes Key research topics in this field include comparative psychology which studies humans in relation other animals perception which involves physical mechanics sensation as well as neural mental processing centuries leading question in biological psychology has been whether mental functions might be localized in brain From Phineas Gage H M Clive Wearing individual people with mental issues traceable physical damage have inspired new discoveries in this area Modern neuropsychology could be said originate in s in France Paul Broca traced production speech left frontal gyrus thereby also demonstrating hemispheric lateralization brain function Soon after Carl Wernicke identified related area necessary understanding speech contemporary field behavioral neuroscience focuses on physical causes underpinning behavior example physiological psychologists use animal models typically rats study neural genetic cellular mechanisms that underlie specific behaviors such as learning memory fear responses Cognitive neuroscientists investigate neural correlates psychological processes in humans using neural imaging tools neuropsychologists conduct psychological assessments determine instance specific aspects extent cognitive deficit caused by brain damage disease biopsychosocial model an integrated perspective toward understanding consciousness behavior social interaction It assumes that any given behavior mental process affects affected by dynamically interrelated biological psychological social factors Evolutionary psychology examines cognition personality traits from an evolutionary perspective This perspective suggests that psychological adaptations evolved solve recurrent problems in human ancestral environments Evolutionary psychology offers complementary explanations mostly proximate developmental explanations developed by other areas psychology that it focuses mostly on ultimate questions rather than proximate questions questions are more directly tackled by behavioral genetics research which aims understand genes environment impact behavior search biological origins psychological phenomena has long involved debates about importance race especially relationship between race intelligence idea white supremacy indeed modern concept race itself arose during process world conquest by Europeans Carl von Linnaeus s four fold classification humans classifies Europeans as intelligent severe Americans as contented free Asians as ritualistic Africans as lazy capricious Race was also used justify construction socially specific mental disorders such as drapetomania dysaesthesia aethiopica behavior uncooperative African slaves After creation experimental psychology ethnical psychology emerged as subdiscipline based on assumption that studying primitive races would provide an important link between animal behavior psychology more evolved humans Behavioral Main articles Behaviorism Psychological behaviorism Radical behaviorism Skinner s teaching machine mechanical invention automate task programmed instruction Psychologists take human behavior as main area study Much research in this area began with tests on mammals based on idea that humans exhibit similar fundamental tendencies Behavioral research ever aspires improve effectiveness techniques behavior modification Play media film Little Albert experiment Early behavioral researchers studied stimulus response pairings now known as classical conditioning They demonstrated that behaviors could be linked through repeated association with stimuli eliciting pain pleasure Ivan Pavlov known best inducing dogs salivate in presence stimulus previously linked with food became leading figure in Soviet Union inspired followers use his methods on humans In United States Edward Lee Thorndike initiated connectionism studies by trapping animals in puzzle boxes rewarding them escaping Thorndike wrote in can be no moral warrant studying man s nature unless study will enable us control his acts From American Psychological Association went through sea change opinion away from mentalism towards behavioralism in John B Watson coined term behaviorism this school thought Watson s famous Little Albert experiment in demonstrated that repeated use upsetting loud noises could instill phobias aversions other stimuli in an infant human Karl Lashley close collaborator with Watson examined biological manifestations learning in brain Embraced extended by Clark L Hull Edwin Guthrie others behaviorism became widely used research paradigm new method instrumental operant conditioning added concepts reinforcement punishment model behavior change Radical behaviorists avoided discussing inner workings mind especially unconscious mind which they considered impossible assess scientifically Operant conditioning was first described by Miller Kanorski popularized in U S by B F Skinner emerged as leading intellectual behaviorist movement Noam Chomsky delivered an influential critique radical behaviorism on grounds that it could not adequately explain complex mental process language acquisition Martin Seligman colleagues discovered that conditioning dogs led outcomes learned helplessness that opposed predictions behaviorism Skinner s behaviorism did not die perhaps in part it generated successful practical applications Edward C Tolman advanced hybrid cognitive behaviorial model most notably with his publication discussing cognitive maps used by rats guess at location food at end modified maze Association Behavior Analysis International was founded in by had members from countries field has been especially influential in Latin America it has regional organization known as ALAMOC La Asociaci n Latinoamericana de An lisis y Modificaci n del Comportamiento Behaviorism also gained strong foothold in Japan it gave rise Japanese Society Animal Psychology Japanese Association Special Education Japanese Society Biofeedback Research Japanese Association Behavior Therapy Japanese Association Behavior Analysis Japanese Association Behavioral Science Research Today field behaviorism also commonly referred as behavior modification behavior analysis Cognitive Main article Cognitive psychology Green Red Blue Purple Blue Purple Blue Purple Red Green Purple Green Stroop effect refers fact that naming color first set words easier quicker than second Cognitive psychology studies cognition mental processes underlying mental activity Perception attention reasoning thinking problem solving memory learning language emotion are areas research Classical cognitive psychology associated with school thought known as cognitivism whose adherents argue an information processing model mental function informed by functionalism experimental psychology Baddeley s model working memory Starting in s experimental techniques developed by Wundt James Ebbinghaus others re emerged as experimental psychology became increasingly cognitivist concerned with information its processing eventually constituted part wider cognitive science Some called this development cognitive revolution it rejected anti mentalist dogma behaviorism as well as strictures psychoanalysis Social learning theorists such as Albert Bandura argued that child s environment could make contributions its own behaviors an observant subject M ller Lyer illusion Psychologists make inferences about mental processes from shared phenomena such as optical illusions Technological advances also renewed interest in mental states representations English neuroscientist Charles Sherrington Canadian psychologist Donald O Hebb used experimental methods link psychological phenomena with structure function brain rise computer science cybernetics artificial intelligence suggested value comparatively studying information processing in humans machines Research in cognition had proven practical since World War II it aided in understanding weapons operation popular representative topic in this area cognitive bias irrational thought Psychologists economists have classified described sizeable catalogue biases which recur frequently in human thought availability heuristic example tendency overestimate importance something which happens come readily mind citation needed Elements behaviorism cognitive psychology were synthesized form cognitive behavioral therapy form psychotherapy modified from techniques developed by American psychologist Albert Ellis American psychiatrist Aaron T Beck On broader level cognitive science an interdisciplinary enterprise cognitive psychologists cognitive neuroscientists researchers in artificial intelligence linguists human computer interaction computational neuroscience logicians social scientists discipline cognitive science covers cognitive psychology as well as philosophy mind computer science neuroscience citation needed Computer simulations are sometimes used model phenomena interest Social Main article Social psychology See also Social psychology sociology Social psychology studies nature causes social behavior Social psychology study humans think about each other they relate each other Social psychologists study such topics as influence others on an individual s behavior e g conformity persuasion formation beliefs attitudes stereotypes about other people Social cognition fuses elements social cognitive psychology in order understand people process remember distort social information study group dynamics reveals information about nature potential optimization leadership communication other phenomena that emerge at least at microsocial level In recent years many social psychologists have become increasingly interested in implicit measures mediational models interaction both person social variables in accounting behavior study human society therefore potentially valuable source information about causes psychiatric disorder Some sociological concepts applied psychiatric disorders are social role sick role social class life event culture migration social total institution citation needed Psychoanalysis Main articles Psychodynamics psychoanalysis Group photo in front Clark University Front row Sigmund Freud G Stanley Hall Carl Jung back row Abraham Brill Ernest Jones S ndor Ferenczi Psychoanalysis comprises method investigating mind interpreting experience systematized set theories about human behavior form psychotherapy treat psychological emotional distress especially conflict originating in unconscious mind This school thought originated in s with Austrian medical doctors including Josef Breuer physician Alfred Adler physician Otto Rank psychoanalyst most prominently Sigmund Freud neurologist Freud s psychoanalytic theory was largely based on interpretive methods introspection clinical observations It became very well known largely it tackled subjects such as sexuality repression unconscious These subjects were largely taboo at time Freud provided catalyst open discussion in polite society Clinically Freud helped pioneer method free association therapeutic interest in dream interpretation Swiss psychiatrist Carl Jung influenced by Freud elaborated theory collective unconscious primordial force present in all humans featuring archetypes which exerted profound influence on mind Jung s competing vision formed basis analytical psychology which later led archetypal process oriented schools Other well known psychoanalytic scholars mid th century include Erik Erikson Melanie Klein D W Winnicott Karen Horney Erich Fromm John Bowlby Sigmund Freud s daughter Anna Freud Throughout th century psychoanalysis evolved into diverse schools thought which could be called Neo Freudian Among these schools are ego psychology object relations interpersonal Lacanian relational psychoanalysis citation needed Psychologists such as Hans Eysenck philosophers including Karl Popper criticized psychoanalysis Popper argued that psychoanalysis had been misrepresented as scientific discipline whereas Eysenck said that psychoanalytic tenets had been contradicted by experimental data By end th century psychology departments in American universities mostly marginalized Freudian theory dismissing it as desiccated dead historical artifact However researchers in emerging field neuro psychoanalysis today defend some Freud s ideas on scientific grounds while scholars humanities maintain that Freud was not scientist at all but an interpreter Existential humanistic theories Main articles Existential psychology Humanistic psychology Psychologist Abraham Maslow in posited that humans have hierarchy needs it makes sense fulfill basic needs first food water etc before higher order needs can be met Humanistic psychology developed in s as movement within academic psychology in reaction both behaviorism psychoanalysis humanistic approach sought glimpse whole person not just fragmented parts personality isolated cognitions Humanism focused on uniquely human issues such as free will personal growth self actualization self identity death aloneness freedom meaning It emphasized subjective meaning rejection determinism concern positive growth rather than pathology citation needed Some founders humanistic school thought were American psychologists Abraham Maslow formulated hierarchy human needs Carl Rogers created developed client centered therapy Later positive psychology opened up humanistic themes scientific modes exploration American Association Humanistic Psychology formed in declared Humanistic psychology primarily an orientation toward whole psychology rather than distinct area school It stands respect worth persons respect differences approach open mindedness as acceptable methods interest in exploration new aspects human behavior As third force in contemporary psychology it concerned with topics having little place in existing theories systems e g love creativity self growth organism basic need gratification self actualization higher values being becoming spontaneity play humor affection naturalness warmth ego transcendence objectivity autonomy responsibility meaning fair play transcendental experience peak experience courage related concepts In s s influenced by philosophers S ren Kierkegaard Martin Heidegger psychoanalytically trained American psychologist Rollo May pioneered an existential branch psychology which included existential psychotherapy method based on belief that inner conflict within person due that individual s confrontation with givens existence Swiss psychoanalyst Ludwig Binswanger American psychologist George Kelly may also be said belong existential school Existential psychologists differed from more humanistic psychologists in relatively neutral view human nature relatively positive assessment anxiety Existential psychologists emphasized humanistic themes death free will meaning suggesting that meaning can be shaped by myths narrative patterns that it can be encouraged by an acceptance free will requisite an authentic albeit often anxious regard death other future prospects Austrian existential psychiatrist Holocaust survivor Viktor Frankl drew evidence meaning s therapeutic power from reflections garnered from his own internment He created variation existential psychotherapy called logotherapy type existentialist analysis that focuses on will meaning in one s life as opposed Adler s Nietzschean doctrine will power Freud s will pleasure Themes Personality Main article Personality psychology Personality psychology concerned with enduring patterns behavior thought emotion commonly referred as personality in individuals Theories personality vary across different psychological schools orientations They carry different assumptions about such issues as role unconscious importance childhood experience According Freud personality based on dynamic interactions id ego super ego In order develop taxonomy personality constructs trait theorists in contrast attempt describe personality sphere in terms discrete number key traits using statistical data reduction method factor analysis Although number proposed traits has varied widely an early biologically based model proposed by Hans Eysenck rd mostly highly cited psychologist th Century after Freud Piaget respectively suggested that at least three major trait constructs are necessary describe human personality structure extraversion introversion neuroticism stability psychoticism normality Raymond Cattell th most highly cited psychologist th Century based on scientific peer reviewed journal literature empirically derived theory personality factors at primary factor level up broader second stratum factors at Eysenckian level analysis rather than Big Five dimensions Dimensional models personality are receiving increasing support version dimensional assessment has been included in DSM V However despite plethora research into various versions Big Five personality dimensions it appears necessary move on from static conceptualizations personality structure more dynamic orientation whereby it acknowledged that personality constructs are subject learning change across lifespan An early example personality assessment was Woodworth Personal Data Sheet constructed during World War popular although psychometrically inadequate Myers Briggs Type Indicator sought assess individuals personality types according personality theories Carl Jung Behaviorist resistance introspection led development Strong Vocational Interest Blank Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory MMPI in an attempt ask empirical questions that focused less on psychodynamics respondent However MMPI has been subjected critical scrutiny given that it adhered archaic psychiatric nosology since it required individuals provide subjective introspective responses hundreds items pertaining psychopathology Unconscious mind See also Unconscious mind Psychology Study unconscious mind part psyche outside awareness individual which nevertheless influenced thoughts behavior was hallmark early psychology In one first psychology experiments conducted in United States C S Peirce Joseph Jastrow found in that subjects could choose minutely heavier two weights even if consciously uncertain difference Freud popularized this concept with terms like Freudian slip entering popular culture mean an uncensored intrusion unconscious thought into one s speech action His text Psychopathology Everyday Life catalogues hundreds everyday events which Freud explains in terms unconscious influence Pierre Janet advanced idea subconscious mind which could contain autonomous mental elements unavailable scrutiny subject Behaviorism notwithstanding unconscious mind has maintained its importance in psychology Cognitive psychologists have used filter model attention according which much information processing takes place below threshold consciousness only certain processes limited by nature by simultaneous quantity make way through filter Copious research has shown that subconscious priming certain ideas can covertly influence thoughts behavior significant hurdle in this research proving that subject s conscious mind has not grasped certain stimulus due unreliability self reporting this reason some psychologists prefer distinguish between implicit explicit memory In another approach one can also describe subliminal stimulus as meeting an objective but not subjective threshold automaticity model which became widespread following exposition by John Bargh others in s describes sophisticated processes executing goals which can be selected performed over an extended duration without conscious awareness Some experimental data suggests that brain begins consider taking actions before mind becomes aware them This influence unconscious forces on people s choices naturally bears on philosophical questions free will John Bargh Daniel Wegner Ellen Langer are some prominent contemporary psychologists describe free will as an illusion Motivation Main article Motivation Psychologists such as William James initially used term motivation refer intention in sense similar concept will in European philosophy With steady rise Darwinian Freudian thinking instinct also came be seen as primary source motivation According drive theory forces instinct combine into single source energy which exerts constant influence Psychoanalysis like biology regarded these forces as physical demands made by organism on nervous system However they believed that these forces especially sexual instincts could become entangled transmuted within psyche Classical psychoanalysis conceives struggle between pleasure principle reality principle roughly corresponding id ego Later in Beyond Pleasure Principle Freud introduced concept death drive compulsion towards aggression destruction psychic repetition traumatic events Meanwhile behaviorist researchers used simple dichotomous models pleasure pain reward punishment well established principles such as idea that thirsty creature will take pleasure in drinking Clark Hull formalized latter idea with his drive reduction model Hunger thirst fear sexual desire thermoregulation all seem constitute fundamental motivations animals Humans also seem exhibit more complex set motivations though theoretically these could be explained as resulting from primordial instincts including desires belonging self image self consistency truth love control Motivation can be modulated manipulated in many different ways Researchers have found that eating example depends not only on organism s fundamental need homeostasis an important factor causing experience hunger but also on circadian rhythms food availability food palatability cost Abstract motivations are also malleable as evidenced by such phenomena as goal contagion adoption goals sometimes unconsciously based on inferences about goals others Vohs Baumeister suggest that contrary need desire fulfilment cycle animal instincts human motivations sometimes obey getting begets wanting rule more get reward such as self esteem love drugs money more want it They suggest that this principle can even apply food drink sex sleep Development Main article Developmental psychology Developmental psychologists would engage child with book then make observations based on child interacts with object Mainly focusing on development human mind through life span developmental psychology seeks understand people come perceive understand act within world these processes change as they age This may focus on cognitive affective moral social neural development Researchers study children use number unique research methods make observations in natural settings engage them in experimental tasks Such tasks often resemble specially designed games activities that are both enjoyable child scientifically useful researchers have even devised clever methods study mental processes infants In addition studying children developmental psychologists also study aging processes throughout life span especially at other times rapid change such as adolescence old age Developmental psychologists draw on full range psychological theories inform research citation needed Genes environment Main article Behavioral genetics All researched psychological traits are influenced by both genes environment varying degrees These two sources influence are often confounded in observational research individuals families An example transmission depression from depressed mother her offspring Theory may hold that offspring by virtue having depressed mother in his her offspring s environment at risk developing depression However risk depression also influenced some extent by genes mother may both carry genes that contribute her depression but will also have passed those genes on her offspring thus increasing offspring s risk depression Genes environment in this simple transmission model are completely confounded Experimental quasi experimental behavioral genetic research uses genetic methodologies disentangle this confound understand nature origins individual differences in behavior Traditionally this research has been conducted using twin studies adoption studies two designs genetic environmental influences can be partially un confounded More recently availability microarray molecular genetic genome sequencing technologies allows researchers measure participant DNA variation directly test whether individual genetic variants within genes are associated with psychological traits psychopathology through methods including genome wide association studies One goal such research similar that in positional cloning its success in Huntington s once causal gene discovered biological research can be conducted understand that gene influences phenotype One major result genetic association studies general finding that psychological traits psychopathology as well as complex medical diseases are highly polygenic large number on order hundreds thousands genetic variants each small effect contribute individual differences in behavioral trait propensity disorder Active research continues understand genetic environmental bases behavior interaction Applications Further information Outline psychology List psychology disciplines Applied psychology Subfields psychology Psychology encompasses many subfields includes different approaches study mental processes behavior Mental testing See also Psychometrics social statistics Psychological testing has ancient origins such as examinations Chinese civil service dating back BC Written exams began during Han dynasty BC AD By Chinese system required stratified series tests involving essay writing knowledge diverse topics system was ended in In Europe mental assessment took more physiological approach with theories physiognomy judgment character based on face described by Aristotle in th century BC Greece Physiognomy remained current through Enlightenment added doctrine phrenology study mind intelligence based on simple assessment neuroanatomy experimental psychology came Britain Francis Galton was leading practitioner with his procedures measuring reaction time sensation considered an inventor modern mental testing also known as psychometrics James McKeen Cattell student Wundt Galton brought concept United States in fact coined term mental test In Cattell s student Clark Wissler published discouraging results suggesting that mental testing Columbia Barnard students failed predict academic performance In response orders from Minister Public Instruction French psychologists Alfred Binet Th odore Simon elaborated new test intelligence in using range questions diverse in nature difficulty Binet Simon introduced concept mental age referred lowest scorers on test as idiots Henry H Goddard put Binet Simon scale work introduced classifications mental level such as imbecile feebleminded In after Binet s death Stanford professor Lewis M Terman modified Binet Simon scale renamed Stanford Binet scale introduced intelligence quotient as score report From this test Terman concluded that mental retardation represents level intelligence which very very common among Spanish Indians Mexican families Southwest also among negroes dullness seems be racial Following Army Alpha Army Beta tests soldiers in World War mental testing became popular in US it was soon applied school children federally created National Intelligence Test was administered million children in s in College Entrance Examination Board created Scholastic Aptitude Test standardize college admissions results intelligence tests were used argue segregated schools economic functions i e preferential training Black Americans manual labor These practices were criticized by black intellectuals such Horace Mann Bond Allison Davis Eugenicists used mental testing justify organize compulsory sterilization individuals classified as mentally retarded In United States tens thousands men women were sterilized Setting precedent which has never been overturned U S Supreme Court affirmed constitutionality this practice in case Buck v Bell Today mental testing routine phenomenon people all ages in Western societies Modern testing aspires criteria including standardization procedure consistency results output an interpretable score statistical norms describing population outcomes ideally effective prediction behavior life outcomes outside testing situations Mental health care provision psychological health services generally called clinical psychology in U S definitions this term are various may include school psychology counseling psychology Practitioners typically includes people have graduated from doctoral programs in clinical psychology but may also include others In Canada above groups usually fall within larger category professional psychology In Canada US practitioners get bachelor s degrees doctorates then spend one year in an internship one year in postdoctoral education In Mexico most other Latin American European countries psychologists do not get bachelor s doctorate degrees instead they take three year professional course following high school Clinical psychology at present largest specialization within psychology It includes study application psychology purpose understanding preventing relieving psychologically based distress dysfunction mental illness promote subjective well being personal development Central its practice are psychological assessment psychotherapy although clinical psychologists may also engage in research teaching consultation forensic testimony program development administration Credit first psychology clinic in United States typically goes Lightner Witmer established his practice in Philadelphia in Another modern psychotherapist was Morton Prince most part in first part twentieth century most mental health care in United States was performed by specialized medical doctors called psychiatrists Psychology entered field with its refinements mental testing which promised improve diagnosis mental problems part some psychiatrists became interested in using psychoanalysis other forms psychodynamic psychotherapy understand treat mentally ill In this type treatment specially trained therapist develops close relationship with patient discusses wishes dreams social relationships other aspects mental life therapist seeks uncover repressed material understand patient creates defenses against certain thoughts feelings An important aspect therapeutic relationship transference in which deep unconscious feelings in patient reorient themselves become manifest in relation therapist Psychiatric psychotherapy blurred distinction between psychiatry psychology this trend continued with rise community mental health facilities behavioral therapy thoroughly non psychodynamic model which used behaviorist learning theory change actions patients key aspect behavior therapy empirical evaluation treatment s effectiveness In s cognitive behavior therapy arose using similar methods now including cognitive constructs which had gained popularity in theoretical psychology key practice in behavioral cognitive behavioral therapy exposing patients things they fear based on premise that responses fear panic anxiety can be deconditioned Mental health care today involves psychologists social workers in increasing numbers In National Institute Mental Health director Bertram Brown described this shift as source intense competition role confusion Graduate programs issuing doctorates in psychology PsyD emerged in s underwent rapid increase through s This degree intended train practitioners might conduct scientific research Some clinical psychologists may focus on clinical management patients with brain injury this area known as clinical neuropsychology In many countries clinical psychology regulated mental health profession emerging field disaster psychology see crisis intervention involves professionals respond large scale traumatic events work performed by clinical psychologists tends be influenced by various therapeutic approaches all which involve formal relationship between professional client usually an individual couple family small group Typically these approaches encourage new ways thinking feeling behaving Four major theoretical perspectives are psychodynamic cognitive behavioral existential humanistic systems family therapy has been growing movement integrate various therapeutic approaches especially with an increased understanding issues regarding culture gender spirituality sexual orientation With advent more robust research findings regarding psychotherapy evidence that most major therapies have equal effectiveness with key common element being strong therapeutic alliance this more training programs psychologists are now adopting an eclectic therapeutic orientation Diagnosis in clinical psychology usually follows Diagnostic Statistical Manual Mental Disorders DSM handbook first published by American Psychiatric Association in New editions over time have increased in size focused more on medical language study mental illnesses called abnormal psychology Education Main articles Educational psychology School psychology An example an item from cognitive abilities test used in educational psychology Educational psychology study humans learn in educational settings effectiveness educational interventions psychology teaching social psychology schools as organizations work child psychologists such as Lev Vygotsky Jean Piaget Jerome Bruner has been influential in creating teaching methods educational practices Educational psychology often included in teacher education programs in places such as North America Australia New Zealand School psychology combines principles from educational psychology clinical psychology understand treat students with learning disabilities foster intellectual growth gifted students facilitate prosocial behaviors in adolescents otherwise promote safe supportive effective learning environments School psychologists are trained in educational behavioral assessment intervention prevention consultation many have extensive training in research Work See also Industrial organizational psychology Organizational behavior Industrialists soon brought nascent field psychology bear on study scientific management techniques improving workplace efficiency This field was at first called economic psychology business psychology later industrial psychology employment psychology psychotechnology An important early study examined workers at Western Electric s Hawthorne plant in Cicero Illinois from With funding from Laura Spelman Rockefeller Fund guidance from Australian psychologist Elton Mayo Western Electric experimented on thousands factory workers assess responses illumination breaks food wages researchers came focus on workers responses observation itself term Hawthorne effect now used describe fact that people work harder they think they re being watched name industrial organizational psychology O arose in s became enshrined as Society Industrial Organizational Psychology Division American Psychological Association in goal optimize human potential in workplace Personnel psychology subfield O psychology applies methods principles psychology in selecting evaluating workers O psychology s other subfield organizational psychology examines effects work environments management styles on worker motivation job satisfaction productivity majority O psychologists work outside academia private public organizations as consultants psychology consultant working in business today might expect provide executives with information ideas about industry target markets organization company Military intelligence One role psychologists in military evaluate counsel soldiers other personnel In U S this function began during World War Robert Yerkes established School Military Psychology at Fort Oglethorpe in Georgia provide psychological training military staff military Today U S Army psychology includes psychological screening clinical psychotherapy suicide prevention treatment post traumatic stress as well as other aspects health workplace psychology such as smoking cessation Psychologists may also work on diverse set campaigns known broadly as psychological warfare Psychological warfare chiefly involves use propaganda influence enemy soldiers civilians In case so called black propaganda propaganda designed seem like it originates from different source CIA s MKULTRA program involved more individualized efforts at mind control involving techniques such as hypnosis torture covert involuntary administration LSD U S military used name Psychological Operations PSYOP until these were reclassified as Military Information Support Operations MISO part Information Operations IO Psychologists are sometimes involved in assisting interrogation torture suspects though this has sometimes been denied by those involved sometimes opposed by others Health well being social change See also health psychology Biopsychosocial model Medical facilities increasingly employ psychologists perform various roles prominent aspect health psychology psychoeducation patients instructing them in follow medical regimen Health psychologists can also educate doctors conduct research on patient compliance Psychologists in field public health use wide variety interventions influence human behavior These range from public relations campaigns outreach governmental laws policies Psychologists study composite influence all these different tools in an effort influence whole populations people Black American psychologists Kenneth Mamie Clark studied psychological impact segregation testified with findings in desegregation case Brown v Board Education Positive psychology study factors which contribute human happiness well being focusing more on people are currently healthy In Clinical Psychological Review published special issue devoted positive psychological interventions such as gratitude journaling physical expression gratitude Positive psychological interventions have been limited in scope but effects are thought be superior that placebos especially with regard helping people with body image problems Research methods Main articles Psychological research List psychological research methods Quantitative psychological research lends itself statistical testing hypotheses Although field makes abundant use randomized controlled experiments in laboratory settings such research can only assess limited range short term phenomena Thus psychologists also rely on creative statistical methods glean knowledge from clinical trials population data These include Pearson product moment correlation coefficient analysis variance multiple linear regression logistic regression structural equation modeling hierarchical linear modeling measurement operationalization important constructs an essential part these research designs Controlled experiments Main article Experiment Flowchart four phases enrollment intervention allocation follow up data analysis parallel randomized trial two groups modified from CONSORT Statement experimenter E orders teacher T subject experiment give latter believes are painful electric shocks learner L actually an actor confederate subject believes that each wrong answer learner was receiving actual electric shocks though in reality were no such punishments Being separated from subject confederate set up tape recorder integrated with electro shock generator which played pre recorded sounds each shock level etc true experiment with random allocation subjects conditions allows researchers make strong inferences about causal relationships In an experiment researcher alters parameters influence called independent variables measures resulting changes interest called dependent variables Prototypical experimental research conducted in laboratory with carefully controlled environment Repeated measures experiments are those which take place through intervention on multiple occasions In research on effectiveness psychotherapy experimenters often compare given treatment with placebo treatments compare different treatments against each other Treatment type independent variable dependent variables are outcomes ideally assessed in several ways by different professionals Using crossover design researchers can further increase strength results by testing both two treatments on two groups subjects Quasi experimental design refers especially situations precluding random assignment different conditions Researchers can use common sense consider much nonrandom assignment threatens study s validity example in research on best way affect reading achievement in first three grades school school administrators may not permit educational psychologists randomly assign children phonics whole language classrooms in which case psychologists must work with preexisting classroom assignments Psychologists will compare achievement children attending phonics whole language classes Experimental researchers typically use statistical hypothesis testing model which involves making predictions before conducting experiment then assessing well data supports predictions These predictions may originate from more abstract scientific hypothesis about phenomenon under study actually works Analysis variance ANOVA statistical techniques are used distinguish unique results experiment from null hypothesis that variations result from random fluctuations in data In psychology widely used standard ascribes statistical significance results which have less than probability being explained by random variation Other forms statistical inference Statistical surveys are used in psychology measuring attitudes traits monitoring changes in mood checking validity experimental manipulations other psychological topics Most commonly psychologists use paper pencil surveys However surveys are also conducted over phone through e mail Web based surveys are increasingly used conveniently reach many subjects Neuropsychological tests such as Wechsler scales Wisconsin Card Sorting Test are mostly questionnaires simple tasks used which assess specific type mental function in respondent These can be used in experiments as in case lesion experiments evaluating results damage specific part brain Observational studies analyze uncontrolled data in search correlations multivariate statistics are typically used interpret more complex situation Cross sectional observational studies use data from single point in time whereas longitudinal studies are used study trends across life span Longitudinal studies track same people therefore detect more individual rather than cultural differences However they suffer from lack controls from confounding factors such as selective attrition bias introduced certain type subject disproportionately leaves study Exploratory data analysis refers variety practices which researchers can use visualize analyze existing sets data In Peirce s three modes inference exploratory data analysis corresponds abduction hypothesis formation Meta analysis technique integrating results from multiple studies interpreting statistical properties pooled dataset Technological assays An EEG recording setup classic popular tool used relate mental neural activity electroencephalogram EEG technique using amplified electrodes on person s scalp measure voltage changes in different parts brain Hans Berger first researcher use EEG on an unopened skull quickly found that brains exhibit signature brain waves electric oscillations which correspond different states consciousness Researchers subsequently refined statistical methods synthesizing electrode data identified unique brain wave patterns such as delta wave observed during non REM sleep Newer functional neuroimaging techniques include functional magnetic resonance imaging positron emission tomography both which track flow blood through brain These technologies provide more localized information about activity in brain create representations brain with widespread appeal They also provide insight which avoids classic problems subjective self reporting It remains challenging draw hard conclusions about in brain specific thoughts originate even usefully such localization corresponds with reality However neuroimaging has delivered unmistakable results showing existence correlations between mind brain Some these draw on systemic neural network model rather than localized function model Psychiatric interventions such as transcranial magnetic stimulation drugs also provide information about brain mind interactions Psychopharmacology study drug induced mental effects Artificial neural network with two layers an interconnected group nodes akin vast network neurons in human brain Computer simulation See also Computational cognition Computational modeling tool used in mathematical psychology cognitive psychology simulate behavior This method has several advantages Since modern computers process information quickly simulations can be run in short time allowing high statistical power Modeling also allows psychologists visualize hypotheses about functional organization mental events that couldn t be directly observed in human Computational neuroscience uses mathematical models simulate brain Another method symbolic modeling which represents many mental objects using variables rules Other types modeling include dynamic systems stochastic modeling Animal studies rat undergoing Morris water navigation test used in behavioral neuroscience study role hippocampus in spatial learning memory Animal experiments aid in investigating many aspects human psychology including perception emotion learning memory thought name few In s Russian physiologist Ivan Pavlov famously used dogs demonstrate classical conditioning Non human primates cats dogs pigeons rats other rodents are often used in psychological experiments Ideally controlled experiments introduce only one independent variable at time in order ascertain its unique effects upon dependent variables These conditions are approximated best in laboratory settings In contrast human environments genetic backgrounds vary so widely depend upon so many factors that it difficult control important variables human subjects are pitfalls in generalizing findings from animal studies humans through animal models Comparative psychology refers scientific study behavior mental processes non human animals especially as these relate phylogenetic history adaptive significance development behavior Research in this area explores behavior many species from insects primates It closely related other disciplines that study animal behavior such as ethology Research in comparative psychology sometimes appears shed light on human behavior but some attempts connect two have been quite controversial example Sociobiology E O Wilson Animal models are often used study neural processes related human behavior e g in cognitive neuroscience Qualitative descriptive research Research designed answer questions about current state affairs such as thoughts feelings behaviors individuals known as descriptive research Descriptive research can be qualitative quantitative in orientation Qualitative research descriptive research that focused on observing describing events as they occur with goal capturing all richness everyday behavior with hope discovering understanding phenomena that might have been missed if only more cursory examinations have been made Qualitative psychological research methods include interviews first hand observation participant observation Creswell identifies five main possibilities qualitative research including narrative phenomenology ethnography case study grounded theory Qualitative researchers sometimes aim enrich interpretations critiques symbols subjective experiences social structures Sometimes hermeneutic critical aims can give rise quantitative research as in Erich Fromm s study Nazi voting citation needed Stanley Milgram s studies obedience authority Phineas P Gage survived an accident in which large iron rod was driven completely through his head destroying much his brain s left frontal lobe remembered that injury s reported effects on his personality behavior Just as Jane Goodall studied chimpanzee social family life by careful observation chimpanzee behavior in field psychologists conduct naturalistic observation ongoing human social professional family life Sometimes participants are aware they are being observed other times participants do not know they are being observed Strict ethical guidelines must be followed covert observation being carried out Program Evaluation Program Evaluation systematic method collecting analyzing using information answer questions about projects policies programs particularly about effectiveness efficiency In both public private sectors stakeholders often want know whether programs they are funding implementing voting receiving objecting are producing intended effect While program evaluation first focuses around this definition important considerations often include much program costs per participant program could be improved whether program worthwhile whether are better alternatives if are unintended outcomes whether program goals are appropriate useful Contemporary issues in methodology practice Metascience field metascience has revealed significant problems with methodology psychological research Psychological research suffers from high bias low reproducibility widespread misuse use statistics These finding have led calls reform from within from outside scientific community Confirmation bias In statistician Theodore Sterling examined results psychological studies discovered that them supported initial hypotheses implying possible publication bias Similarly Fanelli found that psychiatry psychology studies confirmed effects they were looking concluded that odds this happening positive result was around five times higher than in fields such as space geosciences Fanelli argues that this researchers in softer sciences have fewer constraints conscious unconscious biases Replication Further information Replication crisis In psychology Over subsequent few years replication crisis in psychology was identified it was publicly noted that many notable findings in field had not been replicated with some researchers being accused outright fraud in results More systematic efforts assess extent problem such as Reproducibility Project Center Open Science found that as many as two thirds highly publicized findings in psychology had failed be replicated with reproducibility being generally stronger in studies journals representing cognitive psychology than social psychology topics subfields personality psychology behavioral genetics related field behavioral economics being largely unaffected by replication crisis with exception candidate gene candidate gene by environment interaction research on behavior mental illness in behavioral genetics Other subfields psychology that have been implicated by replication crisis are clinical psychology developmental psychology field closely related psychology that has also been implicated educational research Focus on replication crisis has led other renewed efforts in discipline re test important findings in response concerns about publication bias p hacking more than psychology journals have adopted result blind peer review studies are accepted not on basis findings after studies are completed but before studies are conducted upon basis methodological rigor experimental designs theoretical justifications statistical analysis techniques before data collection analysis done In addition large scale collaborations between researchers working in multiple labs in different countries that regularly make data openly available different researchers assess have become much more common in field Early analysis such reforms has estimated that percent result blind studies have led null results in contrast an estimated percent in earlier research Misuse statistics Further information Misuse statistics Misuse p values Some critics view statistical hypothesis testing as misplaced Psychologist statistician Jacob Cohen wrote in that psychologists routinely confuse statistical significance with practical importance enthusiastically reporting great certainty in unimportant facts Some psychologists have responded with an increased use effect size statistics rather than sole reliance on p values citation needed WEIRD bias WEIRD redirects here other uses see Weird In Arnett pointed out that most articles in American Psychological Association journals were about US populations U S citizens are only world s population He complained that psychologists had no basis assuming psychological processes be universal generalizing research findings rest global population In Henrich Heine Norenzayan reported systemic bias in conducting psychology studies with participants from WEIRD western educated industrialized rich democratic societies Although only people worldwide live in regions that fall into WEIRD classification researchers claimed that psychology studies are performed on participants from these areas article gave examples results that differ significantly between people from WEIRD tribal cultures including M ller Lyer illusion Arnett Altmaier Hall Morgan Consoli et al saw Western bias in research theory as serious problem considering psychologists are increasingly applying psychological principles developed in WEIRD regions in research clinical work consultation with populations around world In Rad Martingano Ginges showed that nearly decade after Henrich et al s paper over samples used in studies published in journal Psychological Science were from WEIRD population Moreover analysis showed that several studies did not fully disclose origin samples authors offer set recommendations editors reviewers reduce WEIRD bias Kurtis Adams Grabe Else Quest Collins Machizawa Rice describe transnational feminist psychology also called transnational psychology that applies transnational feminist lenses field psychology study understand address impact colonization imperialism globalization In order counter Western bias in field psychology Kurtis Adams suggested that people in non Western Majority World areas majority world s population lives be viewed as resources revising traditional psychological science They proposed applying principles transnational feminism developed through interdisciplinary work in postcolonial feminist studies using context sensitive cultural psychology lens reconsider de naturalize de universalize psychological science In Summit was organized by Machizawa Collins Rice further develop transnational psychology It led presentations publications that applied transnational psychological perspectives various topics in psychology Grabe Else Quest proposed concept transnational intersectionality that expands current conceptions intersectionality adding global forces analysis oppressive institutions are interconnected In addition Bhatia believes that transnational cultural psychology needed examine psychology diasporas are impacted by globalization consequently have many homes languages selves Unscientific mental health training Some observers perceive gap between scientific theory its application in particular application unsupported unsound clinical practices Critics say has been an increase in number mental health training programs that do not instill scientific competence Practices such as facilitated communication infantile autism memory recovery techniques including body work other therapies such as rebirthing reparenting may be dubious even dangerous despite popularity In Allen Neuringer made similar point vague regarding experimental analysis behavior Psychologists sometimes divided along lines laboratory vs clinic continue
